senior_executives.name: Bela Bajaria
senior_executives.title: Chief Content Officer

mandate.overview: Oversees all global content strategy, greenlighting decisions for $17B+ annual content budget. Final decision-maker for tentpole series, overall deals with A-list talent, and strategic franchise bets.
current_priorities: Fewer, bigger bets on proven IP and talent
Global franchises that travel across all regions
Prestige limited series for awards momentum
Cost discipline while maintaining quality bar
mandate.pitch_pathway: Never direct. Must come through head of genre (Peter Friedlander for US Scripted, Anne Mensah for UK, etc.) with full package and business case. Bela reviews only projects that have cleared genre head approval and require C-level sign-off due to budget/strategic importance.
mandate.decision_timeline: 2-4 weeks after genre head approval for tentpoles, 4-8 weeks for overall deals
success_factors: Clear global appeal and franchise potential
Strong business case (cost per hour vs projected viewing)
Strategic fit with Netflix brand and retention goals

senior_executives.background: Former President of Universal Television, joined Netflix 2016. Promoted to Chief Content Officer 2020. Known for data-driven decisions balanced with creative instincts. Champions diverse voices and global storytelling.
public_statements: We're making fewer shows, but they're bigger and better.
The goal is to have something for everyone, but not everything for someone.
We're focused on shows that can break through globally, not just in one market.

senior_executives.name: Peter Friedlander
senior_executives.title: Head of US Scripted Series

mandate.overview: Oversees all US scripted series development and production. Greenlights drama, limited series, and comedy originating from US market. Reports to Bela Bajaria.
decision_authority: US scripted series budgets up to $50M total
current_priorities: Prestige limited series for awards (Emmy, Golden Globe)
mandate.pitch_pathway: Through production company with Netflix overall/first-look deal, or via top-tier agency packaging. Requires: pilot script or bible, showrunner attachment, talent package, budget estimate, comp titles.
mandate.decision_timeline: 4-8 weeks for initial read, 8-12 weeks for greenlight decision after pitch
success_factors: Tight episode count (6-10 for limited, 8-10 for season 1)
Global hook that travels beyond US

senior_executives.background: Former EVP Warner Bros. Television, joined Netflix 2017. Oversees hits like Ozark, The Crown, Stranger Things (US production). Known for supporting auteur showrunners and prestige storytelling.
public_statements: We're looking for shows that feel like events, not just episodes.
The bar is high because the competition is fierce.
Limited series are our secret weapon for awards and prestige.

senior_executives.name: Jinny Howe
senior_executives.title: VP, Drama Series

mandate.overview: Oversees drama series development globally, working across regions to identify and greenlight ongoing drama series with multi-season potential.
mandate.pitch_pathway: Through production partners or international studios. Prefers projects with international elements or co-production potential.

senior_executives.background: Former ABC Studios executive, joined Netflix 2018. Champions character-driven storytelling and international collaborations.

decision_hierarchy.description: Netflix content decision-making flows through a tiered system based on project scale and budget

tiers.typical_projects: Stranger Things, Bridgerton, Wednesday, Avatar: The Last Airbender

tiers.tier: Head of Genre (Peter Friedlander, Anne Mensah, etc.)
tiers.typical_projects: House of Guinness, The Diplomat, Baby Reindeer, 3 Body Problem

tiers.tier: VP Level (Jinny Howe, Kennedy Corrin, etc.)
tiers.typical_projects: The Night Agent, Partner Track, The Watcher

netflix_advantages: Proven hit-making machine with data-driven greenlighting
Faster time-to-market (6-12 months vs Apple's 12-18 months)
Binge-release model drives immediate cultural impact
apple_advantages: Higher per-project budgets (willing to spend $20M+ per episode)
More creator-friendly terms (better backend, more control)
vs_apple_tv_plus.when_to_choose_netflix: Global reach, franchise potential, binge appeal, faster greenlight-to-release, data-driven marketing

netflix_advantages: Pure streaming focus vs Amazon's bundled offering
amazon_advantages: Larger overall budget (willing to overpay for tentpoles)
vs_amazon_prime.when_to_choose_netflix: Pure streaming play, international focus, consistent strategy, faster decisions

netflix_advantages: Higher volume of content (more shots on goal)
vs_hbo_max.when_to_choose_netflix: Global reach, volume strategy, binge appeal, faster cultural impact

netflix_unique_value_props: Binge-release model for immediate cultural conversation
Proven track record of creating global hits from any region
Willingness to take risks on new voices and formats

limited_series.success_factors: Full script, A-list talent attached, awards potential, tight episode count (6-8)

drama_series_new.success_factors: Pilot script + bible, showrunner with track record, clear 3-season arc, global hook

overall_deal.deal_structure: Typically 2-4 year term, $10M-$100M+ depending on talent
overall_deal.success_factors: Proven track record, multiple project ideas, strategic fit with Netflix priorities

international_co_production.success_factors: Strong local partner, global appeal, cost-sharing structure, regional authenticity

seasonal_patterns.q1_jan_mar: Post-holidays: Focus on awards season results, planning summer/fall releases
seasonal_patterns.q2_apr_jun: Upfronts season: Major greenlight activity, overall deal announcements
seasonal_patterns.q3_jul_sep: Emmy season: Prestige focus, fall release planning
seasonal_patterns.q4_oct_dec: Holiday releases, year-end tentpoles, next-year planning
